metadata.dc:author: Micheli, F
Lehkuniec, E
Gatto, E
metadata.dc:description: We describe a patient with a longstanding paraplegia who developed spinal myoclonus on 3 different occasions spanning one year, once after an enhanced CT scan and twice after excretory urographies, one of which was also followed by a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. To our knowledge only one case of spinal myoclonus secondary to the administration of intravenous contrast material in a patient with a spinal arteriovenous malformation has yet been reported. Taken together, the findings in these cases suggest that spinal myoclonus following intravenous iodine administration is indicative of an underlying spinal cord lesion.
metadata.dc:title: Mioclonus espinal secundario a la administraci√≥n endovenosa de contraste iodado.
[Spinal myoclonus secondary to the intravenous administration of iodine contrast media].
